instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> is missing.
Signals that will make the PCH produce <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are also present.
1.<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> -3.3V
2. <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
3. <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
4. [B]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 2.3V[/B]
5. [B]<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 2.3V[/B]
6. <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K</SIGNAL>
7. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
8. <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.3V
9. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3V
10. <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
11. [B]<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.0V[/B].
Sometimes, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is intermittently present, but if I withdraw power and restore it, it goes missing again.
- With charger plugged in nothing happened
- Triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, there was no reaction at all.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
"Signals that will make the PCH produce <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are also present."
Don't make assumption so easy.
PCH will not release <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> until gets the drop pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>!
Check that when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; supposing it has 3V steady.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> went low when I triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, it also has a steady 3.4V

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message: Didn't note any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time?

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message: There was a pulse, but, it went to 1V and back to 0V

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
An o-scope can catch peak pulse; 3.3V probably.
If DC voltmeter shown 1V, there is pulse for sure.

That means S3 voltage pulse too; like L7520 and <RESISTOR>R8011</RESISTOR>.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> reaction too.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> was pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> at L7520 was also pulsing 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8011</RESISTOR> was also pulsing

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
Also check at CPU coils and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
There's pulse at pin 3 and 7 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
 CPU coils L7320 and L7310  also has pulse
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> was also pulsing

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming on
threads.message:
Any history available?
Possibly crap accumulated underneath PCH/CPU.
Try to burn it, using quality flux.
